dt: {bc}a printing proof that incorporates changes marked in a previous proof

shortdef: a printing proof that incorporates changes marked in a previous proof

dt: {bc}to look over again in order to correct or improve
{bc}to make a new, amended, improved, or up-to-date version of
{bc}to provide with a new taxonomic arrangement

pt: {sc}correct{/sc} {sc}rectify{/sc} {sc}emend{/sc} {sc}remedy{/sc} {sc}redress{/sc} {sc}amend{/sc} {sc}reform{/sc} {sc}revise{/sc} mean to make right what is wrong. {sc}correct{/sc} implies taking action to remove errors, faults, deviations, defects.
{sc}rectify{/sc} implies a more essential changing to make something right, just, or properly controlled or directed.
{sc}emend{/sc} specifically implies correction of a text or manuscript.
{sc}remedy{/sc} implies removing or making harmless a cause of trouble, harm, or evil.

pt.t: set out to {it}remedy{/it} the evils of the world

pt: {sc}redress{/sc} implies making compensation or reparation for an unfairness, injustice, or imbalance.
{sc}amend{/sc} {sc}reform{/sc} {sc}revise{/sc} imply an improving by making corrective changes, {sc}amend{/sc} usually suggesting slight changes
, and {sc}revise{/sc} suggesting a careful examination of something and the making of necessary changes.

et: Middle French {it}reviser{/it}, from Latin {it}revisere{/it} to look at again, frequentative of {it}revidēre{/it} to see again, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}vidēre{/it} to see {ma}{mat|wit|}{/ma}
shortdef: to look over again in order to correct or improve
